DOC.TEXT: Orders to U.S. factories for durable goods posted a 5.1 percent gain in November, the sharpest increase in a year, the government said. Analysts said the report suggested the economy can avoid a recession. The Commerce Department said Friday that orders for durable goods _ costly items expected to last at least three years _ increased to a seasonally adjusted $130.7 billion last month after dropping 0.7 percent in October and 1.2 percent in September. The gain in orders was spread through all categories and was the largest since a 7.4 percent jump last December. It averted the first three-month decline since 1986.

The Senate Ethics Committee said it will formally investigate five senators who intervened with banking regulators on behalf of a wealthy contributor whose huge savings and loan was failing. The senators all have denied wrongdoing and said they welcomed the announcement. The ethics panel said Friday it will probe the activities of Majority Whip Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Banking Committee Chairman Donald W. Riegle, Jr., D-Mich.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio.

Bank of New England Corp., which expects heavy losses due to bad real estate loans, has rescinded a common stock dividend declared last month. The announcement Friday came one week after Bank of New England said it would boost its loan reserves above $1 billion and that it expected a ``substantial'' loss for the year. The bank struggled amid a regional real estate slump.

Smithkline Beecham PLC, a major international pharmaceutical company, has agreed to sell its U.S. and Canadian household products businesses to a West German company for $107 million in cash. Smithkline said Friday the sale to Joh. A. Benckiser GmbH is consistent with its strategy of focusing on international healthcare following the merger of Smithkline Beckman Corp. with Beecham Group PLC earlier this year. Household products included in the sale are Calgon, a leading U.S. bath additive, Cling Free, a fabric softener used in driers, and Delicare, a detergent for delicate products.

Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. has put McCann-Erickson Worldwide in charge of placing domestic advertising for both its Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures movies. The decision Friday could mean an extra $70 million to $75 million in annual billings for the giant New York-based agency, which had previously held the assignment for placing only the Columbia Pictures ads. The loser is AC&R Advertising, a unit of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Co. PLC which had been responsible for placing the Tri-State Pictures advertising.

Ford Motor Co. intends to sell $1.55 billion in debt securities to pay for its recent acquisition of Associates, the nation's third-largest independent finance company, according to documents. In a registration statement filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ford said it is seeking to issue the debt securities through Ford Holdings Inc., a subsidiary formed in September to acquire Associates. The debt securities will be sold ``to reduce short-term debt, including borrowings to fund the acquisition of Associates,'' according to the registration statement.

A federal judge has unsealed confidential corporate documents in a lawsuit against Mobil Oil Corp. but withheld the order when lawyers for the oil giant said they would appeal. The company is fighting to prevent the disclosure of the documents _ reports on environmental conditions at its chemical division plants _ because it says they are self-critical evaluations. Disclosing such reports would have a chilling effect on a company's efforts to be candid about its operations, Mobil argued Friday.

The Bush administration plans to lift a congressional ban on government loans to Iraq, a move expected to antagonize lawmakers critical of Iraq's human rights abuses and credit problems. Officials say President Bush will exercise his right to lift the ban, imposed by Congress several months ago, on grounds of U.S. national interests. The officials said the move is expected within several weeks. U.S. oil companies and other businesses have exerted heavy pressure on the administration to broaden trade ties with Iraq since the 1988 end of its ruinous 8-year war with Iran.

Westinghouse Electric Corp. is considering appealing for an increase in the $3.9 million bonus it won for running the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant despite safety lapses such as workers sleeping on the job, an Energy Department official said. Westinghouse officials at the South Carolina plant, however, said Friday there were no plans to appeal.

The stock market worked its way higher in quiet preholiday trading Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 20.26 points to 2,711.39, cutting its loss for the week to 28.16 points. The dollar tumbled in abbreviated pre-Christmas foreign-exchange trading. Bond prices fell. Orange juice futures prices fell sharply; heating oil futures posted fresh gains as the nation's record-setting cold spell continued; precious metals advanced; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.
